Award.AwardTitle: Planning grant: I/UCRC for Biophotonic Sensors and Systems, New Site
Award.AbstractNarration:
Purdue University is planning to join the I/UCRC on Biophotonic Sensors and Systems (CBSS) as a new university site. CBSS has a goal to establish a national center of excellence in biophotonic sensor and system research, cultivate embryonic biosensor applications, develop methods for improved technology transfer and train a pipeline of skilled engineers and scientist to work in this field. Ultimately, CBSS intends to provide solutions for disease diagnosis, patient monitoring, drug efficacy testing and improved food and water safety. Purdue will expand the scope of corporate connections and brings exciting complementary areas of research to support the CBSS mission.

The Purdue team will offer research topics including: compressive optical imaging, flow cytometry, nonlinear optical microscopy, single cell detection, biodynamic imaging of 3D tissues, and point of care medical devices. These research topics fit perfectly with the current CBSS research thrusts and roadmap areas of Imaging, Bioanalytics and Diagnositcs.
The Purdue Site Director (Dr. Ji-Xin Cheng) has extensive connections in industry that include Olympus and Leica, which offer products in their portfolios based on his inventions. Companies that intend to participate in the planning meeting include companies such as Johnson & Johnson,Ocean Optics and Riverside Research, which are committing to full membership.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A team of interdisciplinary Purdue faculty was assembled to prepare Purdue as a new site for the Boston University based I/UCRC: Center for Biophotonics Sensors and System (CBSS). The Purdue faculty included Garth Simpson and Dor ben-Amotz in Department of Chemistry, Paul Robinson, Ji-Xin Cheng and Ouyang Zheng in Weldon School of Biomedical Engineering, David Nolte in Department of Physics, and Joseph Irudayaraj in Department of Agricultural and Biological Engineering. The team contributed a total of 9 research projects. In April 2015, the Purdue team had a planning meeting in joint with the I/UCTC annual meeting at Boston University Photonics Center. A total of 5 Purdue faculty members jointed this planning meeting. Porfessor Ji-Xin Cheng introduced the Purdue team and the facilities at Purdue that matches the mission of the CBSS I/UCRC. The Purdue team presented 5 projects, including “compressing sensing of living cells” by Professor Ben-Amotz, High-throughput High-content single-cell Analysis by Stimulated Raman Scattering Flow Cytometry by Chi Zhang in Ji-Xin Cheng group, Point of care analysis of biofluids and tissue samples by Zheng Ouyang group. These projects were well received by the attendees and reviewed by an external evaluator. Through this planning meeting, the Purdue team learned the features to be a good project for I/UCRC: it needs to be applied but can be in the early stage of the development.The team also grasped the critical requirement, i.e., three full company membership, for submitting a full proposal. The Purdue team experienced some difficulty in soliciting the financial support from the industrial partners.
